entry.summary: It's interesting to reflect on how my taste in games has changed over the years. Back in my 20's, I was into Counterstrike. Nowadays, kids in their 20's are into Counterstrike. But I've gotten older. My day is a lot of work. I'm solving problems…
entry.content:
It's interesting to reflect on how my taste in games has changed over the years. Back in my 20's, I was into Counterstrike. Nowadays, kids in their 20's are into Counterstrike.

But I've gotten older.

My day is a lot of work. I'm solving problems all the time, in both business and family. How can I get my daughter to eat broccoli? (answer: once she finishes, she gets a pancake). How can I build a game that is both true to myself as a creator and commercially viable? (answer: TBD). How can my wife and I have an intimate and fulfilling relationship when we are literally never alone? (answer: please email me, haven't got this one figured out).

So yeah, once I sit down to "play a game", I've just gotten done playing several games concurrently with varying degrees of success. I don't really want to learn new rules, compete against people who have invested time I'll never have, or, well, in essence, lose. I don't really want to lose. I want to play games that are just fun to play. If they are win or lose games, I want to win. 

That means multiplayer games are generally out because humans like winning and everyone can't win. Sorry LIBTARDS! Man what a terrible word that is! But still, it's true. Everyone cannot win unless the game is designed to not be won at all.

That said, some games can only be lost, and somehow that is a happy place to be. Maybe part of reaching this point in life is recognizing that many games are a battle to simply survive. So survival games where eventual death is either lurking over the hill or right on top of you, tend to be quite appealing.

entry.content:
So yeah I'm using Publii for this and I have been really wringing my hands over it, but today I got editing of the content from multiple computers working well. Publii is like a really stripped down and simplified Wordpress, but instead of requiring an entire stack of server based tech, it is just a program you can install on Windows.

This might seem like a step backwards if you can only edit your stuff from one computer, but fortunately, it's possible to store the source data in Dropbox and sync it between more than one machine. 

Anyway I don't really want to make this entire blog about having a blog, but after facing nightmare scenario of using Jekyll and writing posts in Markdown (yeesh), this is amazing.

To make this post not a complete waste, here's the entrance to Unity '09 in San Francisco. Unity spared no expense. I think this was the Unite where they announced a free version.

entry.title: And so it begins.
entry.summary: I've always wanted to be free with sharing what I'm doing, but there's always been a reason why I didn't. NDAs and employment agreements at Sony and Activision make employees invisible. I left that life in 2015, but right after got so deep into making…
entry.content:
I've always wanted to be free with sharing what I'm doing, but there's always been a reason why I didn't. NDAs and employment agreements at Sony and Activision make employees invisible. I left that life in 2015, but right after got so deep into making Headmaster that I didn't dedicate the time. I think there is a saying about planting a tree, and yesterday, and something. It's a very smart saying. You can imagine.

Anyway, I've started to get busy doing my own stuff again. It's exciting and scary, but I'm determined to not hermit again.

It's been a few weeks and I've been tinkering on some code... an old little space shooter project that I'm fixing up like a beat up car. I want to talk about it a bit, so here we go. 

BTW this blog is built with a thing called Publii. It's like Wordpress, but the app is on your computer and it generates the site as html/css. It seems cool, so giving it a shot. I gave "fancy" static site generators like Jekyll and Hugo a good look, but you have to be a web head to get these things. Ain't got time for that.

entry.title: Headmaster VR at the 2017 UEFA Champions League Final — Part 2
entry.summary: In Part 1 of this series, I ended with us heading to the UEFA Champions League Final with Playstation. Our trip was easy and upon arrival in Cardiff we walked from our hotel downtown to the Champions League Festival on Cardiff Bay. When I wrote Part 1, we…
entry.content:
In Part 1 of this series, I ended with us heading to the UEFA Champions League Final with Playstation. Our trip was easy and upon arrival in Cardiff we walked from our hotel downtown to the Champions League Festival on Cardiff Bay. When I wrote Part 1, we didn’t have clearance to announce what it was all about, but Playstation ran a Headmaster tournament where the winner received two tickets to the match! This was an incredible opportunity and we were super excited to be there for it.

The Winner

The tournament ran Thursday, Friday, and Saturday until 1pm. Kristin and I happened to visit the booth right around then. We looked over and saw this man with tears in his eyes. We quickly came to find out that he was the winner. It was then that I really understood how precious those tickets were.

Chris was from Cardiff and came down to the festival on Friday, played Headmaster a few times, but didn’t quite reach the top of the leaderboard. His first score was 600. He told us he went home that night and couldn’t sleep because he was so consumed with strategizing how to get a higher score. He came back on Saturday and played three more times, getting first place on his last ball. He beat the next closest player by 20 points.

 

The Champions Village

Right after the Tournament ended, it was time to head over to the match. We were a part of Playstation’s group, so we had passes to The Champions Village, which is like an all inclusive mini-resort to hang out at for a couple hours before game time. If there is a polar opposite to tailgating at a Buffalo Bills game, this was it. These guys have some good video of the experience and make it look appropriately fancy.

 

Just like last year, inside the Champions Village was a Playstation hospitality “tent” with free food, drink, and another Headmaster station. But even better than last year, the fine gents from Playstation Access came by and ran up the scores, recording the whole bit. The video below should go right to the proper time for Headmaster business, but their whole video is another fun look at what it was like to be there at the match.

The Match

After we ate and drank and hung out at the Champions Village, we made our way over to the stadium. This video gives a first hand account of that walk from the time we left the village until we sat in our seats.

 

Highlight of the trip

Even after seeing the match itself, Kristin and I consider meeting the winner and the runners up of the Headmaster tournament as the highlights of our trip.

 

Thanks to Playstation

We’d like to say thanks especially to James Olivier and Leiana Tran of Playstation for inviting us to be a part of this event and working with us over the past few months.

 

Random Cardiff Photos

Cardiff is a great town with a vast walkable area. We explored a lot in between all the events.

I offer these photos without comment.

entry.title: 2016 Champions League Final
entry.summary: This post is a backdated record of my trip to Milan for the UEFA Champions League final in 2016, where Headmaster was used as a promotional vehicle for Playstation VR. It was an amazing opportunity I never expected. The 2016 festival venue was by the…
entry.content:
This post is a backdated record of my trip to Milan for the UEFA Champions League final in 2016, where Headmaster was used as a promotional vehicle for Playstation VR. It was an amazing opportunity I never expected.

The 2016 festival venue was by the Milan Cathedral, an absolutely gigantic structure with an open square surrounding it. I managed to edit together some iPhone footage of it for posterity.

At one point Dutch football legend Ruud Gullit found his way into the game and of course killed it. He even started taunting his son to give it a try. In a nice way I think?

This festival runs for a few days and is pretty much just a giant roiling football party. I spent my time with some other developers who have become good friends. Guy Richards, who was at the time our man on the inside of Playstation Europe, was a fantastic host. Andreas Johnsson of Tarsier Studios (Statik, Little Nightmares) and I improved diplomatic relations between the USA and Sweden by exchanging our currencies. It was funny, just a couple days ago we were talking on Skype about Gamedev Things™ and realized we both have been carrying these notes around since then and both of us, at that moment, had no other cash. He has a $2 bill and I have this 20 Kronor note.

I was also fortunate to get to know Ilari Kuittinen of Housemarque (Alienation, Resogun) who had just started to talk about his studio’s collaboration with Eugene Jarvis on what has now been announced as Nex Machina.

Match Day 2016

On match day, we arrived at Milan’s San Siro stadium early for some food and drink in the Playstation FC Hospitality area, which also had a station for people to play Headmaster. I caught this shakycam footage of a stroll around the place, ending with some folks gawking at an unsuspecting player making a go of it.

After pregaming in this area for a few hours, we made our way to our seats and this is where I started to get really excited. I’m a pretty avid fan and this is just a huge match in a huge stadium. I am quite sure was built with alien technology. It is enormous.

And below is a video which is an attempt to capture the vibe of walking into the stadium. On the left of the frame you’ll see Andreas and Ilari, along with Guy Richards (now of XBox) making fun of me for holding my phone on top of my head but I GOT THIS VIDEO NOW HOW YA LIKE THAT! The audio in this clip brings back some great memories and hopefully it captures a fraction of what it’s like to be met with a wall of 80,000 chanting fans.
